title: Saving the Home of a Famous Song
summary: Campaigners are working hard to save Ellisland Farm, a historic place in Scotland where Robert Burns wrote the famous song 'Auld Lang Syne'. They need to raise £12 million to fix the farm because it has problems like damp and decay. The farm is very old and important, and they want to make it a fun place for people to visit, with a museum and other attractions. A special film was made to show why the farm matters. The leaders of the trust, like Duncan Dornan and Joan McAlpine, believe this project will help the local economy and inspire everyone. They have already raised some money and plan to share more details next year.

background_read: Robert Burns was a famous Scottish poet who lived long ago and wrote many songs and poems, including 'Auld Lang Syne', which people sing on New Year's Eve. Ellisland Farm is where he lived and worked, making it a special historic site. Campaigners are groups of people who raise money and awareness to protect important places like this for everyone to enjoy in the future.

WHAT: Trying to raise £12 million to restore Ellisland Farm and turn it into a cultural destination
WHERE: Ellisland Farm north of Dumfries in Scotland
WHY: To save the historic building from decay and inspire people with Burns' legacy
